column2: Shooting-matches are probably nearly coeval with the colonization of Georgia.
column3: Shooting matches are probably nearly coeval with the colonization of Georgia.

column2: They are still common throughout the Southern States, though they are not as common as they were twenty-five or thirty years ago. Chance led me to one about a year ago.
column3: They are still common throughout the Southern States, though they are not as common as they were twenty five or thirty years ago. Chance led me to one about a year ago.

column2: I was traveling in one of the northeastern counties, when I overtook a swarthy, bright-eyed, smirky little fellow, riding a small pony, and bearing on his shoulder a long, heavy rifle, which, judging from its looks, I should say had done service in Morgan's corps.

column2: Good morning, sir! said I, reining up my horse as I came beside him.

column2: How goes it, stranger? said he, with a tone of independence and self-confidence that awakened my curiosity to know a little of his character.

column2: Unless your way lies through the woods from here, said Billy, "it'll not be much out of your way; for it's only a mile ahead of us, and there is no other road for you to take till you get there; and as that thing you're riding in ain't well suited to fast traveling among brushy knobs, I reckon you won't lose much by going by.

column2: Come along, Lyman, and I'll go my death upon you at the shooting-match, with the old Soap-stick at your shoulder."

column2: Ah, Billy, said I, "the old Soap-stick will do much better at your own shoulder.

column2: It was my mother's notion that sent me to the shooting-match at Berry Adams's; and, to tell the honest truth, it was altogether a chance shot that made me win beef; but that wasn't generally known; and most everybody believed that I was carried there on account of my skill in shooting; and my fame was spread far and wide, I well remember.

column2: I remember, too, perfectly well, your father's bet on me at the store. _He_ was at the shooting-match, and nothing could make him believe but that I was a great shot with a rifle as well as a shot-gun.
column3: I remember, too, perfectly well, your father's bet on me at the store. underscore He underscore was at the shooting match, and nothing could make him believe but that I was a great shot with a rifle as well as a shot gun.

column2: It so happened, too, that there were but two bullets, or, rather, a bullet and a half; and so confident was your father in my skill, that he made me shoot the half bullet; and, strange to tell, by another chance shot, I like to have drove the cross and won his bet."

column2: It went by the name of Sims's Cross Roads, because here two roads intersected each other; and because, from the time that the first had been laid out, Archibald Sims had resided there.

column2: Archibald had been a justice of the peace in his day (and where is the man of his age in Georgia who has not?); consequently, he was called 'Squire Sims.

column2: It is the custom in this state, when a man has once acquired a title, civil or military, to force it upon him as long as he lives; hence the countless number of titled personages who are introduced in these sketches.

column2: The beef was not present, nor is it ever upon such occasions; but several of the company had seen it, who all concurred in the opinion that it was a good beef, and well worth the price that was set upon it--eleven dollars.

column2: A general inquiry ran around, in order to form some opinion as to the number of shots that would be taken; for, of course, the price of a shot is cheapened in proportion to the increase of that number.

column2: In olden times the contest was carried on chiefly with _shot-guns_, a generic term which, in those days, embraced three descriptions of firearms: _Indian-traders_ (a long, cheap, but sometimes excellent kind of gun, that mother Britain used to send hither for traffic with the Indians), _the large musket_, and the _shot-gun_, properly so-called.

column2: Rifles were, however, always permitted to compete with them, under equitable restrictions.
column3: Rifles were, however, always permitted to compete with them, under equitable restrictions.

column2: These were, that they should be fired off-hand, while the shot-guns were allowed a rest, the distance being equal; or that the distance should be one hundred yards for a rifle, to sixty for the shot-gun, the mode of firing being equal.

column2: But this was a match of rifles exclusively; and these are by far the most common at this time.
column3: But this was a match of rifles exclusively; and these are by far the most common at this time.

column2: Most of the competitors fire at the same target; which is usually a board from nine inches to a foot wide, charred on one side as black as it can be made by fire, without impairing materially the uniformity of its surface; on the darkened side of which is _pegged_ a square piece of white paper, which is larger or smaller, according to the distance at which it is to be placed from the marksmen.

column2: This is almost invariably sixty yards, and for it the paper is reduced to about two and a half inches square.
column3: This is almost invariably sixty yards, and for it the paper is reduced to about two and a half inches square.

column2: Out of the center of it is cut a rhombus of about the width of an inch, measured diagonally; this is the _bull's-eye_, or _diamond_, as the marksmen choose to call it; in the center of this is the cross.

column2: But every man is permitted to fix his target to his own taste; and accordingly, some remove one-fourth of the paper, cutting from the center of the square to the two lower corners, so as to leave a large angle opening from the center downward; while others reduce the angle more or less: but it is rarely the case that all are not satisfied with one of these figures.

column2: Just on the right-hand side of the bull's-eye, was the reply.

column2: I looked with all the power of my eyes, but was unable to discover the least change in the surface of the paper.

column2: The next in order was Hiram Baugh.
column3: The next in order was Hiram Baugh.

column2: Hiram was like some race-horses which I have seen; he was too good not to contend for every prize, and too good for nothing ever to win one.
column3: Hiram was like some race horses which I have seen; he was too good not to contend for every prize, and too good for nothing ever to win one.

column2: Gentlemen, said he, as he came to the mark, "I don't say that I'll win beef; but if my piece don't blow, I'll eat the paper, or be mighty apt to do it, if you'll b'lieve my racket.
column3: Gentlemen, said he, as he came to the mark, "I don't say that I'll win beef; but if my piece don't blow, I'll eat the paper, or be mighty apt to do it, if you'll b'lieve my racket.

column2: My powder are not good powder, gentlemen; I bought it _thum_ (from) Zeb Daggett, and gin him three-quarters of a dollar a pound for it; but it are not what I call good powder, gentlemen; but if old Buck-killer burns it clear, the boy you call Hiram Baugh eat's paper, or comes mighty near it."
column3: My powder are not good powder, gentlemen; I bought it underscore thum underscore (from) Zeb Daggett, and gin him three quarters of a dollar a pound for it; but it are not what I call good powder, gentlemen; but if old Buck killer burns it clear, the boy you call Hiram Baugh eat's paper, or comes mighty near it."

column2: How long you gwine stand thar talking 'fore you shoot?"
column3: How long you gwine stand thar talking 'fore you shoot?"

column3: Never mind, said Hiram, "I can talk a little and shoot a little, too, but that's nothin'.

column2: Hiram assumed the figure of a note of interrogation, took a long sight, and fired.

column2: You'll not win beef, and never did."

column2: He then wiped out his rifle, rubbed the pan with his hat, drew a piece of tow through the touch-hole with his wiper, filled his charger with great care, poured the powder into the rifle with equal caution, shoved in with his finger the two or three vagrant grains that lodged round the mouth of his piece, took out a handful of bullets, looked them all over carefully, selected one without flaw or wrinkle, drew out his patching, found the most even part of it, sprung open the grease-box in the breech of his rifle; took up just so much grease, distributed it with great equality over the chosen part of his patching, laid it over the muzzle of his rifle, grease side down, placed his ball upon it, pressed it a little, then took it up and turned the neck a little more perpendicularly downward, placed his knife handle on it, just buried it in the mouth of the rifle, cut off the redundant patching just above the bullet, looked at it, and shook his head in token that he had cut off too much or too little, no one knew which, sent down the ball, measured the contents of his gun with his first and second fingers on the protruding part of the ramrod, shook his head again, to signify there was too much or too little powder, primed carefully, placed an arched piece of tin over the hind sight to shade it, took his place, got a friend to hold his hat over the foresight to shade it, took a very long sight, fired, and didn't even eat the paper.

column2: Oh, you didn't take time, said Mealy.
column3: Oh, you didn't take time, said Mealy.

column2: The next was Moses Firmby.

column2: He was a tall, slim man, of rather sallow complexion; and it is a singular fact, that though probably no part of the world is more healthy than the mountainous parts of Georgia, the mountaineers have not generally robust frames or fine complexions: they are, however, almost inexhaustible by toil.

column2: Moses kept us not long in suspense.

column2: His rifle was already charged, and he fixed it upon the target with a steadiness of nerve and aim that was astonishing to me and alarming to all the rest.

column2: A few seconds, and the report of his rifle broke the deathlike silence which prevailed.
column3: A few seconds, and the report of his rifle broke the deathlike silence which prevailed.

column2: No great harm done yet, said Spivey, manifestly relieved from anxiety by an event which seemed to me better calculated to produce despair. Firmby's ball had cut out the lower angle of the diamond, directly on a right line with the cross.
column3: No great harm done yet, said Spivey, manifestly relieved from anxiety by an event which seemed to me better calculated to produce despair. Firmby's ball had cut out the lower angle of the diamond, directly on a right line with the cross.

column2: Three or four followed him without bettering his shot; all of whom, however, with one exception, "eat the paper."
column3: Three or four followed him without bettering his shot; all of whom, however, with one exception, "eat the paper."

column2: It now came to Spivey's turn.
column3: It now came to Spivey's turn.

column2: There was nothing remarkable in his person or manner.
column3: There was nothing remarkable in his person or manner.

column2: He took his place, lowered his rifle slowly from a perpendicular until it came on a line with the mark, held it there like a vice for a moment and fired.
column3: He took his place, lowered his rifle slowly from a perpendicular until it came on a line with the mark, held it there like a vice for a moment and fired.

column2: Pretty _sevigrous_, but nothing killing yet, said Billy Curlew, as he learned the place of Spivey's ball.
column3: Pretty underscore sevigrous underscore, but nothing killing yet, said Billy Curlew, as he learned the place of Spivey's ball.

column2: Spivey's ball had just broken the upper angle of the diamond; beating Firmby about half its width.
column3: Spivey's ball had just broken the upper angle of the diamond; beating Firmby about half its width.

column2: A few more shots, in which there was nothing remarkable, brought us to Billy Curlew. Billy stepped out with much confidence, and brought the Soap-stick to an order, while he deliberately rolled up his shirt sleeves.
column3: A few more shots, in which there was nothing remarkable, brought us to Billy Curlew. Billy stepped out with much confidence, and brought the Soap stick to an order, while he deliberately rolled up his shirt sleeves.

column2: Had I judged Billy's chance of success from the looks of his gun, I should have said it was hopeless.
column3: Had I judged Billy's chance of success from the looks of his gun, I should have said it was hopeless.

column3: The stock of Soap stick seemed to have been made with a case knife; and had it been, the tool would have been but a poor apology for its clumsy appearance.

column2: An auger-hole in the breech served for a grease-box; a cotton string assisted a single screw in holding on the lock; and the thimbles were made, one of brass, one of iron, and one of tin.
column3: An auger hole in the breech served for a grease box; a cotton string assisted a single screw in holding on the lock; and the thimbles were made, one of brass, one of iron, and one of tin.

column2: Where's Lark Spivey's bullet? called out Billy to the judges, as he finished rolling up his sleeves.
column3: Where's Lark Spivey's bullet? called out Billy to the judges, as he finished rolling up his sleeves.

column2: About three-quarters of an inch from the cross, was the reply.
column3: About three quarters of an inch from the cross, was the reply.

column2: Well, clear the way! the Soap-stick's coming, and she'll be along in there among 'em presently.
column3: Well, clear the way! the Soap stick's coming, and she'll be along in there among 'em presently.

column2: Billy now planted himself astraddle, like an inverted V; shot forward his left hip, drew his body back to an angle of about forty-five degrees with the plane of the horizon, brought his cheek down close to the breech of old Soap-stick, and fixed her upon the mark with untrembling hand.
column3: Billy now planted himself astraddle, like an inverted V; shot forward his left hip, drew his body back to an angle of about forty five degrees with the plane of the horizon, brought his cheek down close to the breech of old Soap stick, and fixed her upon the mark with untrembling hand.

column2: His sight was long, and the swelling muscles of his left arm led me to believe that he was lessening his chance of success with every half second that he kept it burdened with his ponderous rifle; but it neither flagged nor wavered until Soap-stick made her report.
column3: His sight was long, and the swelling muscles of his left arm led me to believe that he was lessening his chance of success with every half second that he kept it burdened with his ponderous rifle; but it neither flagged nor wavered until Soap stick made her report.

column2: Where am I? said Billy, as the smoke rose from before his eye.
column3: Where am I? said Billy, as the smoke rose from before his eye.

column2: You've jist touched the cross on the lower side, was the reply of one of the judges.
column3: You've jist touched the cross on the lower side, was the reply of one of the judges.

column2: I was afraid I was drawing my bead a _leetle_ too fine, said Billy. "Now, Lyman, you see what the Soap-stick can do.
column3: I was afraid I was drawing my bead a underscore leetle underscore too fine, said Billy. "Now, Lyman, you see what the Soap stick can do.

column2: Take her, and show the boys how you used to do when you was a baby."
column3: Take her, and show the boys how you used to do when you was a baby."

column2: I begged to reserve my shot to the last; pleading, rather sophistically, that it was, in point of fact, one of the Billy's shots. My plea was rather indulged than sustained, and the marksmen who had taken more than one shot commenced the second round.
column3: I begged to reserve my shot to the last; pleading, rather sophistically, that it was, in point of fact, one of the Billy's shots. My plea was rather indulged than sustained, and the marksmen who had taken more than one shot commenced the second round.

column2: This round was a manifest improvement upon the first.
column3: This round was a manifest improvement upon the first.

column2: The cross was driven three times: once by Spivey, once by Firmby, and once by no less a personage than Mealy Whitecotton, whom chance seemed to favor for this time, merely that he might retaliate upon Hiram Baugh; and the bull's-eye was disfigured out of all shape.
column3: The cross was driven three times: once by Spivey, once by Firmby, and once by no less a personage than Mealy Whitecotton, whom chance seemed to favor for this time, merely that he might retaliate upon Hiram Baugh; and the bull's eye was disfigured out of all shape.

column2: The third and fourth rounds were shot.
column3: The third and fourth rounds were shot.

column2: Billy discharged his last shot, which left the rights of parties thus: Billy Curlew first and fourth choice, Spivey second, Firmby third and Whitecotton fifth.
column3: Billy discharged his last shot, which left the rights of parties thus: Billy Curlew first and fourth choice, Spivey second, Firmby third and Whitecotton fifth.

column2: Some of my readers may perhaps be curious to learn how a distinction comes to be made between several, all of whom drive the cross.
column3: Some of my readers may perhaps be curious to learn how a distinction comes to be made between several, all of whom drive the cross.

column2: The distinction is perfectly natural and equitable.
column3: The distinction is perfectly natural and equitable.

column2: Threads are stretched from the uneffaced parts of the once intersecting lines, by means of which the original position of the cross is precisely ascertained.
column3: Threads are stretched from the uneffaced parts of the once intersecting lines, by means of which the original position of the cross is precisely ascertained.

column2: Each bullet-hole being nicely pegged up as it is made, it is easy to ascertain its circumference.
column3: Each bullet hole being nicely pegged up as it is made, it is easy to ascertain its circumference.

column2: To this I believe they usually, if not invariably, measure, where none of the balls touch the cross; but if the cross be driven, they measure from it to the center of the bullet-hole. To make a draw shot, therefore, between two who drive the cross, it is necessary that the center of both balls should pass directly through the cross; a thing that very rarely happens.
column3: To this I believe they usually, if not invariably, measure, where none of the balls touch the cross; but if the cross be driven, they measure from it to the center of the bullet hole. To make a draw shot, therefore, between two who drive the cross, it is necessary that the center of both balls should pass directly through the cross; a thing that very rarely happens.

column2: _The Bite_ alone remained to shoot.

column2: Billy wiped out his rifle carefully, loaded her to the top of his skill, and handed her to me.
column3: Billy wiped out his rifle carefully, loaded her to the top of his skill, and handed her to me.

column2: Now, said he, "Lyman, draw a fine bead, but not too fine; for Soap-stick bears up her ball well.
column3: Now, said he, "Lyman, draw a fine bead, but not too fine; for Soap stick bears up her ball well.

column2: Take care and don't touch the trigger until you've got your bead; for she's spring-trigger'd and goes mighty easy: but you hold her to the place you want her, and if she don't go there, dang old Roper."
column3: Take care and don't touch the trigger until you've got your bead; for she's spring trigger'd and goes mighty easy: but you hold her to the place you want her, and if she don't go there, dang old Roper."

column2: I took hold of Soap-stick, and lapsed immediately into the most hopeless despair.
column3: I took hold of Soap stick, and lapsed immediately into the most hopeless despair.

column2: I am sure I never handled as heavy a gun in all my life.
column3: I am sure I never handled as heavy a gun in all my life.

column2: Why, Billy, said I, "you little mortal, you! what do you use such a gun as this for?"
column3: Why, Billy, said I, "you little mortal, you! what do you use such a gun as this for?"

column2: Look at the bull's-eye yonder! said he.
column3: Look at the bull's eye yonder! said he.

column2: True, said I, "but _I_ can't shoot her; it is impossible."
column3: True, said I, "but underscore I underscore can't shoot her; it is impossible."

column2: Go 'long, you old coon! said Billy; "I see what you're at;" intimating that all this was merely to make the coming shot the more remarkable. "Daddy's little boy don't shoot anything but the old Soap-stick here to-day, I know."
column3: Go 'long, you old coon! said Billy; "I see what you're at;" intimating that all this was merely to make the coming shot the more remarkable. "Daddy's little boy don't shoot anything but the old Soap stick here to day, I know."

column2: The judges, I knew, were becoming impatient, and, withal, my situation was growing more embarrassing every second; so I e'en resolved to try the Soap-stick without further parley.
column3: The judges, I knew, were becoming impatient, and, withal, my situation was growing more embarrassing every second; so I e'en resolved to try the Soap stick without further parley.

column2: I stepped out, and the most intense interest was excited all around me, and it flashed like electricity around the target, as I judged from the anxious gaze of all in that direction.
column3: I stepped out, and the most intense interest was excited all around me, and it flashed like electricity around the target, as I judged from the anxious gaze of all in that direction.

column2: Policy dictated that I should fire with a falling rifle, and I adopted this mode; determining to fire as soon as the sights came on a line with the diamond, _bead_ or no _bead_.
column3: Policy dictated that I should fire with a falling rifle, and I adopted this mode; determining to fire as soon as the sights came on a line with the diamond, underscore bead underscore or no underscore bead underscore.

column2: Accordingly, I commenced lowering old Soap-stick; but, in spite of all my muscular powers, she was strictly obedient to the laws of gravitation, and came down with a uniformly accelerated velocity.
column3: Accordingly, I commenced lowering old Soap stick; but, in spite of all my muscular powers, she was strictly obedient to the laws of gravitation, and came down with a uniformly accelerated velocity.

column2: Before I could arrest her downward flight, she had not only passed the target, but was making rapid encroachments on my own toes.
column3: Before I could arrest her downward flight, she had not only passed the target, but was making rapid encroachments on my own toes.

column2: Why, he's the weakest man in the arms I ever seed, said one, in a half whisper.
column3: Why, he's the weakest man in the arms I ever seed, said one, in a half whisper.

column2: It's only his fun, said Billy; "I know him."
column3: It's only his fun, said Billy; "I know him."

column2: It may be fun, said the other, "but it looks mightily like yearnest to a man up a tree."
column3: It may be fun, said the other, "but it looks mightily like yearnest to a man up a tree."

column2: I now, of course, determined to reverse the mode of firing, and put forth all my physical energies to raise Soap-stick to the mark.
column3: I now, of course, determined to reverse the mode of firing, and put forth all my physical energies to raise Soap stick to the mark.

column2: The effort silenced Billy, and gave tongue to all his companions.
column3: The effort silenced Billy, and gave tongue to all his companions.

column2: I had just strength enough to master Soap-stick's obstinate proclivity, and, consequently, my nerves began to exhibit palpable signs of distress with her first imperceptible movement upward.
column3: I had just strength enough to master Soap stick's obstinate proclivity, and, consequently, my nerves began to exhibit palpable signs of distress with her first imperceptible movement upward.

column2: A trembling commenced in my arms; increased, and extended rapidly to my body and lower extremities; so that, by the time that I had brought Soap-stick up to the mark, I was shaking from head to foot, exactly like a man under the continued action of a strong galvanic battery.

column2: In the meantime my friends gave vent to their feelings freely.

column2: I swear poin' blank, said one, "that man can't shoot."

column2: He used to shoot well, said another; "but can't now, nor never could."
column3: He used to shoot well, said another; "but can't now, nor never could."

column3: You better git away from 'bout that mark! bawled a third, "for I'll be d o d darned if Broadcloth don't give some of you the dry gripes if you stand too close thare."

column2: The stranger's got the peedoddles, said a fourth, with humorous gravity.

column3: As soon as I found that Soap stick was high enough (for I made no farther use of the sights than to ascertain this fact), I pulled trigger, and off she went.

column2: I have always found that the most creditable way of relieving myself of derision was to heighten it myself as much as possible.

column2: It is a good plan in all circles, but by far the best which can be adopted among the plain, rough farmers of the country. Accordingly, I brought old Soap-stick to an order with an air of triumph; tipped Billy a wink, and observed, "Now, Billy, 's your time to make your fortune.

column2: Bet 'em two to one that I've knocked out the cross."

column2: Ah, Billy, said I, "I was joking about _betting_, for I never bet; nor would I have you to bet: indeed, I do not feel exactly right in shooting for beef; for it is a species of gaming at last: but I'll say this much: if that cross isn't knocked out, I'll never shoot for beef again as long as I live."
column3: Ah, Billy, said I, "I was joking about underscore betting underscore, for I never bet; nor would I have you to bet: indeed, I do not feel exactly right in shooting for beef; for it is a species of gaming at last: but I'll say this much: if that cross isn't knocked out, I'll never shoot for beef again as long as I live."

column3: By d o d, said Mealy Whitecotton, "you'll lose no great things at that."

column2: It's the greatest take in the world when you learn to drive the cross with it.

column2: Another sort for getting bets upon, to the drop-sight, with a single wabble!

column2: And the Soap-stick's the very yarn for it."

column3: Tell you what, stranger, said one, "you're too hard for us all here. We never underscore hearn underscore o' that sort o' shoot'n' in these parts."

column2: Well, returned I, "you've seen it now, and I'm the boy that can do it."
column3: Well, returned I, "you've seen it now, and I'm the boy that can do it."

column2: The judges were now approaching with the target, and a singular combination of circumstances had kept all my party in utter ignorance of the result of my shot.
column3: The judges were now approaching with the target, and a singular combination of circumstances had kept all my party in utter ignorance of the result of my shot.

column2: Those about the target had been prepared by Billy Curlew for a great shot from me; their expectations had received assurance from the courtesy which had been extended to me; and nothing had happened to disappoint them but the single caution to them against the "dry gripes," which was as likely to have been given in irony as in earnest; for my agonies under the weight of the Soap-stick were either imperceptible to them at the distance of sixty yards, or, being visible, were taken as the flourishes of an expert who wished to "astonish the natives." The other party did not think the direction of my ball worth the trouble of a question; or if they did, my airs and harangue had put the thought to flight before it was delivered.
column3: Those about the target had been prepared by Billy Curlew for a great shot from me; their expectations had received assurance from the courtesy which had been extended to me; and nothing had happened to disappoint them but the single caution to them against the "dry gripes," which was as likely to have been given in irony as in earnest; for my agonies under the weight of the Soap stick were either imperceptible to them at the distance of sixty yards, or, being visible, were taken as the flourishes of an expert who wished to "astonish the natives." The other party did not think the direction of my ball worth the trouble of a question; or if they did, my airs and harangue had put the thought to flight before it was delivered.

column2: Consequently, they were all transfixed with astonishment when the judges presented the target to them, and gravely observed, "It's only second best, after all the fuss."
column3: Consequently, they were all transfixed with astonishment when the judges presented the target to them, and gravely observed, "It's only second best, after all the fuss."

column2: Second best! exclaimed I, with uncontrollable transports.
column3: Second best! exclaimed I, with uncontrollable transports.

column2: The whole of my party rushed to the target to have the evidence of their senses before they would believe the report; but most marvelous fortune decreed that it should be true.
column3: The whole of my party rushed to the target to have the evidence of their senses before they would believe the report; but most marvelous fortune decreed that it should be true.

column2: Their incredulity and astonishment were most fortunate for me; for they blinded my hearers to the real feelings with which the exclamation was uttered, and allowed me sufficient time to prepare myself for making the best use of what I had said before with a very different object.
column3: Their incredulity and astonishment were most fortunate for me; for they blinded my hearers to the real feelings with which the exclamation was uttered, and allowed me sufficient time to prepare myself for making the best use of what I had said before with a very different object.

column2: Second best! reiterated I, with an air of despondency, as the company turned from the target to me.
column3: Second best! reiterated I, with an air of despondency, as the company turned from the target to me.

column2: Second best, only?	Second best, only?
column3: true

column2: Here, Billy, my son, take the old Soap-stick; she's a good piece, but I'm getting too old and dim-sighted to shoot a rifle, especially with the drop-sight and double wabbles."
column3: Here, Billy, my son, take the old Soap stick; she's a good piece, but I'm getting too old and dim sighted to shoot a rifle, especially with the drop sight and double wabbles."

column2: Why, good Lord a'mighty! said Billy, with a look that baffles all description, "an't you _driv_ the cross?"
column3: Why, good Lord a'mighty! said Billy, with a look that baffles all description, "an't you underscore d r i v underscore the cross?"

column2: Oh, driv the cross! rejoined I, carelessly.
column3: Oh, d r i v the cross! rejoined I, carelessly.

column2: What's that!	What's that!
column3: true

column2: Just look where my ball is!
column3: Just look where my ball is!

column2: I do believe in my soul its center is a full quarter of an inch from the cross.
column3: I do believe in my soul its center is a full quarter of an inch from the cross.

column2: I wanted to lay the center of the bullet upon the cross, just as if you'd put it there with your fingers."
column3: I wanted to lay the center of the bullet upon the cross, just as if you'd put it there with your fingers."

column2: Several received this palaver with a contemptuous but very appropriate curl of the nose; and Mealy Whitecotton offered to bet a half pint "that I couldn't do the like again with no sort o' wabbles, he didn't care what." But I had already fortified myself on this quarter of my morality.
column3: Several received this palaver with a contemptuous but very appropriate curl of the nose; and Mealy Whitecotton offered to bet a half pint "that I couldn't do the like again with no sort o' wabbles, he didn't care what." But I had already fortified myself on this quarter of my morality.

column2: A decided majority, however, were clearly of opinion that I was serious; and they regarded me as one of the wonders of the world. Billy increased the majority by now coming out fully with my history, as he had received it from his father; to which I listened with quite as much astonishment as any other one of his hearers.
column3: A decided majority, however, were clearly of opinion that I was serious; and they regarded me as one of the wonders of the world. Billy increased the majority by now coming out fully with my history, as he had received it from his father; to which I listened with quite as much astonishment as any other one of his hearers.

column2: He begged me to go home with him for the night, or, as he expressed it, "to go home with him and swap lies that night, and it shouldn't cost me a cent;" the true reading of which is, that if I would go home with him, and give him the pleasure of an evening's chat about old times, his house should be as free to me as my own.
column3: He begged me to go home with him for the night, or, as he expressed it, "to go home with him and swap lies that night, and it shouldn't cost me a cent;" the true reading of which is, that if I would go home with him, and give him the pleasure of an evening's chat about old times, his house should be as free to me as my own.

column2: But I could not accept his hospitality without retracing five or six miles of the road which I had already passed, and therefore I declined it.
column3: But I could not accept his hospitality without retracing five or six miles of the road which I had already passed, and therefore I declined it.

column2: Well, if you won't go, what must I tell the old woman for you, for she'll be mighty glad to hear from the boy that won the silk handkerchief for her, and I expect she'll lick me for not bringing you home with me.
column3: Well, if you won't go, what must I tell the old woman for you, for she'll be mighty glad to hear from the boy that won the silk handkerchief for her, and I expect she'll lick me for not bringing you home with me.

column2: Tell her, said I, "that I send her a quarter of beef which I won, as I did the handkerchief, by nothing in the world but mere good luck."
column3: Tell her, said I, "that I send her a quarter of beef which I won, as I did the handkerchief, by nothing in the world but mere good luck."

column2: Hold your jaw, Lyman! said Billy; "I an't a gwine to tell the old woman any such lies; for she's a reg'lar built Meth'dist."
column3: Hold your jaw, Lyman! said Billy; "I an't a gwine to tell the old woman any such lies; for she's a reg'lar built Meth'dist."

column2: As I turned to depart, "Stop a minute, stranger!" said one: then lowering his voice to a confidential but distinctly audible tone, "What you offering for?" continued he.
column3: As I turned to depart, "Stop a minute, stranger!" said one: then lowering his voice to a confidential but distinctly audible tone, "What you offering for?" continued he.

column2: I assured him I was not a candidate for anything; that I had accidentally fallen in with Billy Curlew, who begged me to come with him to the shooting-match, and, as it lay right on my road, I had stopped.
column3: I assured him I was not a candidate for anything; that I had accidentally fallen in with Billy Curlew, who begged me to come with him to the shooting match, and, as it lay right on my road, I had stopped.

column2: Oh, said he, with a conciliatory nod, "if you're up for anything, you needn't be mealy-mouthed about it 'fore us boys; for we'll all go in for you here up to the handle."
column3: Oh, said he, with a conciliatory nod, "if you're up for anything, you needn't be mealy mouthed about it 'fore us boys; for we'll all go in for you here up to the handle."

column2: Yes, said Billy, "dang old Roper if we don't go our death for you, no matter who offers.
column3: Yes, said Billy, "dang old Roper if we don't go our death for you, no matter who offers.

column2: If ever you come out for anything, Lyman, jist let the boys of Upper Hogthief know it, and they'll go for you to the hilt, against creation, tit or no tit, that's the _tatur_."
column3: If ever you come out for anything, Lyman, jist let the boys of Upper Hogthief know it, and they'll go for you to the hilt, against creation, tit or no tit, that's the underscore tatur underscore."
